text: Someone help! This pack is too spicy! The only way to ease the heat is by telling me with your pick is! :hot_pepper::hot_pepper::hot_pepper:
Diregraf
Or Looting
Is this a cube?
Dec in stone or mirrorwing for me, great removal or a game ending creature that don't restrict colors much
Make bold choices on your p1p1. Hard in zombies.

I like Geist-Honored Monk a lot, assuming their is token support/ flying support.

Although, Grier Reach Bandit is SO tempting to go in on werewolves.

Yeah, <@U3QMCLQQG>, it’s my Innistrad cube :grin:

U/W Spirits and B/W tokens are both support, as are Werewolves :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:
3 people’s feedback: 6 different answers.
People on Twitter and Fb can’t agree either.
That just means I did a good job with my latest update. The packs have been gas ever since I changed it up
I asked my roommate for his feedback. He’s a much bigger limited fiend than I am.
SICK. Let me know what he thinks. There is a lot of contention in this pack
“I don’t know really know OG innistrad or how it plays with both, so Dec in Stone.”
When in doubt, you can’t go wrong with removal :grin:
There are A LOT of people on Twitter grabbing Faithless Looting. I know it’s good, but do you think it could be people are taking it highly because of all the van talk in Modern? :thinking_face:
It's just a solid card
It definitely is, but over Geist Honored Monk or Declaration in Stone? I don’t disagree, I’m just surprised at its popularity
I often choose card advantage/selection early.
There's also a lot of bad magic players who just assume a card is amazing in edh because it's amazing in modern
Goyf is in 400 decks after all
Not that Faithless Looting is bad or anything
goyf seems good in that golgari scavange guy

I put Looting into most of my red decks, but I don’t swear by it.

I’m just shocked at how much people want to pick it in cube Limited :joy:

I think people tend to over-value looting in EDH. In other formats it's letting you find that key card is gonna turn the tide of the game that has 4 copies in a 60 card deck. Do that a couple times you're gonna find it. EDH you don't get four copies of a silver bullet, it's harder to find anything in a library 40% larger, and you tend to not necessarily have that one game winner you're always looking for.
Again, not that it isn't good, it's just not what it is in modern for example.

I would always run the Looting before I run Tormenting Voice. It’s not something to run on its own because of its power, because like you said, it’s just fine in EDH. People think power translates across formats.
dana, you're also not running combo decks where card quality is what you want
Kinda the Brainstorm thing, where people don't necessarily think through the fact that a lot of the things that make it great in other formats aren't there in EDH
Looting in the paragraph above means the concept, not Faithless Looting in particular.
I hate Brainstorm I’m EDH :unamused:
it's a cornercase card
there's a handful of decks that it's totally acceptable to good
Definitely. I only run it in Locust God. I’ve taken it out of everything else.
As you should

I'm not jealous of whoever talks about card advantage on the wiki due to so many clowns are going to think brainstorm/faithless looting etc as card advantage when they're not. It's velocity and selection, but it's not advantage. Then there will be all the "well actually, in THIS corner case...." people to deal with too
It's also better in 3 color green decks where you have more fetches and more land search ramp to shuffle things away than two color non-green decks.
looting is disadvantageuntil you flashback it
Even Soothesaying makes brainstorm less bad of a choice
You never get back to parity with looting though even w/ the flashback
I've been trying to politely argue with people on the Command Zone discord all morning about that
That you shouldn't be counting cycling lands and Mind Stone as "draw" for your deck
Yeah, you draw a card, but you're not drawing cards.
It's purely a velocity and card selection spell, it is not advantage at any point
I'm trying to figure out how to classify some of this stuff for the draw wiki
I think there are so many classes of draw it's going to be probably the most nuanced section for sure
Not envious

You could go:
Selection - Sylvan Library/Brainstorm/Ponder
Velocity - Looting effects
Advantage - Opportunity/Jace's Ingenuity/cards that leave you + in hand size
Filtering - look at the top x and pick 1 Anticipate/Ancient Stirring effects
Cantrips - Basic draw spells that replace themselves

And then probably a couple other categories and you're still not putting in enough sub categories
Ackshually Sylvan Library CAN be card advantage if you pay the life.
Thank you for proving my previous point
Where as technically Fact or Fiction might not be
Yea, then you get into the FoF/Steam Augury type of spells where every situation is a corner case and there's no real way to put them  into one box
Plus they don't say draw so they don't trigger draw effects for Nekusar, Alhammaret's Archive, etc.
If they don't combo with Abundance I don't want them
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9qw3lkpa5lY>

text: This guy is hilarious.

It’s probably going to just require a definition, ref: Fact or Fiction.
Card just does so much.
I assume the wiki is using tags?

I used to use “dig” as my label for draw effects in totality.
Only if it’s done through time
Does that mean drawing multiple cards is called Cruising? :sunglasses:
I believe that’s just the mythical creature “card advantage” we hear so much about. Or just “draw”
Never heard of that one

Modern Horizons prediction: there will be a cycle of rare lands that plays well with the London mulligan rule.  For example: "When ~ enters the battlefield, reveal the bottom card of your library. If it's a land card, put it in your hand."
Nah, that seems like a loose space for design in a set with limited availability for original cards
Limited availability? Isn't the set supposed to be half originals?
Or are you saying that would be ripe for going in Standard?
I think they want to remove shuffling from the game. Printing lands that can replace fetch lands is critical to that movement.
[[Cellar Door]] tribal confirmed?!

attachments.fallback: Cellar Door {2} // Artifact // {3}, {T}: Target player puts the bottom card of their library into their graveyard. If it's a creature card, you create a 2/2 black Zombie creature token.
attachments.text:
Artifact
{3}, {T}: Target player puts the bottom card of their library into their graveyard. If it's a creature card, you create a 2/2 black Zombie creature token.
_As if anyone needed another reason to avoid dark, dank cellars._
attachments.title: Cellar Door {2}

text: handling your deck like that seems... unadviseable
If they go for a cycle of rare lands at all, it's not likely they'd use them to play around with a mulligan rule that hasn't been fully tested
And yet, Scry and Prowess were declared "evergreen" with almost no testing.
I’m willing to bet on it :slightly_smiling_face:
Anyway, making predictions is fun.
Scry had way more testing than Prowess
But, yeah, I think cards using a mechanic similar to what you've described is unlikely.
Considering that they aren't even sure if they are keeping the London Mulligan yet
And the new mulligan rule isn’t even promised beyond the PT that they’re testing it at....
They aren't 100% positive.
Doesn't mean they don't have confidence in their internal testing.
They have enough confidence to announce it to the world and let pros try to break it
exactly
Well, they have enough confidence to test it in a tournament
They also know that if they want something to be busted let the pros see if it’s healthy or not
“Confidence in internal testing” is different than “designing cards that encourage a brand new form of mulligan that may or may not be adopted by the community”
The sample size of people who would use it at WotC is way too small to unleash it permanently
If they don't fully adopt the mulligan, such a card design would not be problematic for them, would it?
It'd give Grenzo a new tool in EDH. They'd be fine with that.

But they could spend their efforts on something more ubiquitous and less risky. Adding new lands in a set with a limited print run and only half a normal set’s design space for brand new cards with exclusively eternal format applicability at all is risky in the first place
Would they be fine with it in Modern though?
A cycle of 5 new fetches that tap for a colorless BUT only fetch one land type, then they ban fetches from Modern
They still care enough about a format to feature it in 2 GP’s in the same weekend and a brand new set specifically to infuse the format
I doubt they put risky lands for modern in the set for the sake of other formats.
I doubt they design cards that synergize with mulligans. They don’t like to incentivize players to perform against their own best interests. Serum Powder is as far as they’ll go
I don't think they'll do what I said btw

Alright, well. Whatever it ends up requiring, WotC would love to see fetchlands become less of a requirement in Modern. The more general form of the prediction is an attempt at introducing something powerful enough that it can impact Modern in such a way; something that they wouldn't necessarily want in Standard.
But I'm sorry if I pushed anyone's buttons with something too specific.

The whole point of the set is to make an impact on Modern, without screwing up Standard. Everyone's already discussed that there are no color-producing lands that can be reprinted to do that, so I was playing with ideas that would.
Just anarchy, announce modern is moved up to theros ir something
Of note, Modern Horizons is not a limited print run set.

I guess my question is how would these new lands that interact with the bottom of the library supplant fetches in modern then? They’re conditionally going to get you another land if they work the way you presented them, and conditionally good cards don’t see main deck play of any at all
Um... y'all were just telling me that the design would be too risky, and now it's not powerful enough? Heh.

WotC May very well want to get rid of fetches but they’re so ingrained in modern’s deckbuilding and color access at this point that it would take a banning at this point or something more egregious than fetches to push them out. Honestly that may not be a bad thing, but it would almost create a different format altogether.
I didn’t say your design was risky. I said risky lands for modern
And I meant risky as to link these lands to a mulligan rule they don’t even know they will have in place for more than 2 days yet be in the format much longer.
So....yea

They don't need to "link" them. The card wouldn't say anything about mulligans. Introducing a mechanic that plays well with a new rule if adopted, but which has minimal impact if not adopted, isn't risky. It's effectively as close to A-B testing as can be done in an environment that can't support real A-B testing.
So "linking" was a poor word choice on my end. "Designing a new cycle of any card with a specific hypothetical rules change in mind" would be more appropriate
Again, I was just trying to have some fun. Sorry to have wasted anyone's time.
I don't think it was a waste, it was a conversation. Just because I disagreed w/ the execution doesn't mean the conversation was a waste
You're good, Mike.
^I agree with Mat on that
^And dean
If disagreeing w/ someones approach was a waste of time then the EDHRECast should never be given a single listen ever
Sorry, went quiet due to other off-topic topic. My new landlord left the garage half full of their stuff, and am trying to coordiante getting it out before the move Friday.

attachments.fallback: Someone sent a GIF in #off-topic using Tenor

text: Tempting, but I suspect they can afford better lawyers than we can.
And would still require me to move it.  :wink:
Anyway. I don't think WotC's afraid of taking risks with this product, by definition adding that much new content to the format is already risky.
If something ends up being broken, they can ban it, say they're sorry, and will still have made a tremendous amount of money.
Have they said anywhere what the ratio of new cards and reprints is?
50-some od reprints I thought
Gotcha. I just know I hadn’t seen it.
I’m wondering what the ratio of cards that will be “for modern” will be is why I ask. I don’t think they print a large numbers of cards that make a huge impact for the sake of format health.
I thought it was 50/50, but I'd have to rewatch the video to dig that number out.
There are likely to be a lot of reprints and/or functional reprints that are targeted at other formats.
Like The Prof finally getting an Oubliette reprint.

I’m not explaining that correctly/ clearly.

I think Wizards is going to print a lot of role players for modern ala Cabal Therapist that stand out. I’m wondering how many of those we’ll see “aimed” for Modern.
I haven’t seen discussion on Serra so I’m not sure what people’s thoughts on her are.
Agreed. I’m excited to see what gets to bypass standard.
Prof made some good arguments for his top 5 picks. An edict effect, a powerful counterspell, Containment priest.
Not sure about the call on Astral Slide, but I wasn't playing during Onslaught.
Wirewood Symbiote was his other pick.
50 reprints, but wonder how many are draft reprints just to hit that number
My bet is on Counterspell
I'm not sure it's even that strong in a format like modern tbh
My guess is ~65% for draft.
